Name: microtubule-binding region
Description: The motif in the MAPT protein where microtubule binding repeats

Name: tubulin-binding repeat 1
Description: position 569_591 of canonical isoform of MAPT protein

Name: tubulin-binding repeat 2
Description: position 592_621 of canonical isoform of MAPT protein

Name: tubulin-binding repeat 3
Description: position 623_653 of canonical isoform of MAPT protein

Name: tubulin-binding repeat 4
Description: position 654_685 of canonical isoform of MAPT protein

Name: Tau aggregates
Description: Tau (MAPT) in its aggregated form (as Paired Helical Filaments (PHFs) or Straight Filaments (SF)) contains 5–9 moles of phosphate/ mole of the protein, defining it as hyper phosphorylated

Name: hyperphosphorylation
Description: An excessive phosphorylation (see GO:0006468)

Name: GAL80TS
Description: temperature-sensitive allele of GAL80 (tub-GAL80TS)

Name: Tau oligomers
Description: CAST is known to prevent oligomerization of Tau (Rao et al., 2014) and α-synuclein (Diepenbroek et al. 2014) and inhibit reactive gliosis (Rao et al., 2008)

Name: LY293002
Description: a specific PI3-kinase inhibitor

Name: LPLI
Description: Low-power laser irradiation (LPLI) is a non-damage physical therapy

Name: Chronic cerebral hypoperfusion
Description: Chronic cerebral hypoperfusion (CCH) is one of the causes of vascular dementia (VaD) and is also an etiological factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD)

Name: Mori Fructus ethanol extract
Description: ethanol extracted from Mori Fructus, a well-known traditional herbal medicine, food, and dietary supplement

Name: tunneling nanotubes
Description: filamentous-actin-containing membranous structures that bridge and connect cells

Name: amyloidogenesis
Description: production of amyloid

Name: alpha-synuclein aggregates
Description: alpha-synuclein (SNCA) aggregate in fibrillar or oligomeric forms, usually found in Lewy bodies

Name: huntingtin aggregates
Description: huntingtin (HTT) protein fragments aggregations

Name: amyloid-beta aggregates
Description: aggregation of amyloid-beta fragments of the APP protein

Name: SEN-1269
Description: A tau aggregation inhibitor

Name: MLS000034832
Description: A tau aggregation inhibitor

Name: caprospinol
Description: A tau aggregation inhibitor

Name: amyloid-beta oligomers
Description: Small aggregates of amyloid-beta

Name: amyloid-beta 42 oligomers
Description: Amyloid-beta oligomers composed specifically of amyloid-beta 42

Name: APP C-terminally truncated carboxyl-terminal fragments
Description: C-terminally truncated carboxyl-terminal fragments (CTFs) of APP

Name: A2B5 antigen
Description: A2B5 antigen is a cell surface ganglioside epitope expressed on developing thymic epithelial cells, oligodendrocyte progenitors, and neuroendocrine cells.

Name: neutral sphingomyelinase
Description: Sphingomyelin phosphodiesterase (EC 3.1.4.12, also known as neutral sphingomyelinase, sphingomyelinase, or SMase) is a hydrolase enzyme that is involved in sphingolipid metabolism reactions.

Name: Neurodegeneration
Description: Neurodegeneration is the progressive loss of structure or function of neurons, including death of neurons. Many neurodegenerative diseases – including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and Huntington's disease – occur as a result of neurodegenerative processes.

Name: amyloid-beta derived diffusible ligands
Description: soluble oligomeric forms of the amyloid beta peptide known as amyloid-derived diffusible ligands (ADDLs) are the toxic species responsible for neurodegeneration associated with Alzheimer's disease.

Name: Hyperamylinemia
Description: increased secretion of the pancreatic hormone amylin

Name: APOE e4
Description: APOE e4 is a variant of APOE, it's APOE-ε4 (arg112, arg158).

Name: N-AcGIP
Description: N-AcGIP is agonist of GIP

Name: Pro3-GIP
Description: Pro3-GIP is agonist of GIP

Name: PI3K-Akt signaling pathway
Description: PI3K-Akt signaling pathway is an intracellular signaling pathway important in regulating the cell cycle.It is described in KEGG.

Name: Argyrophilic Grain Disease
Description: Argyrophilic grain disease (AGD) is an under-recognized, distinct, highly frequent sporadic tauopathy, with a prevalence reaching 31.3% in centenarians.

Name: granulovacuolar degeneration
Description: Granulovacuolar degeneration (GVD) is one of the pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease (AD), and it is defined as electron-dense granules within double membrane-bound cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Name: mitochondrial dysfunction
Description: mitochondria function disorder

Name: amyloid-beta fibrils
Description: Insoluble fibrous protein aggregates exhibiting beta sheet structure.

Name: AG73
Description: a peptide derived from mouse laminin alpha 1 protein (seq:RKRLQVQLSIRT, chain:2719–2730)

Name: Notch intracellular domain
Description: Notch intracellular domain is the intracellular region of notch receptor.

Name: YENPTY endocytosis motif (APP)
Description: YENTY is the endocytosis motif of Amyloid precursor protein.

Name: sAPP-beta
Description: Soluble amyloid precursor protein

Name: growth factor
Description: A growth factor is a naturally occurring substance capable of stimulating cellular growth, proliferation, healing, and cellular differentiation. Usually it is a protein or a steroid hormone. Growth factors are important for regulating a variety of cellular processes.

Name: 3R tau
Description: Tau isoforms containing 3 tubulin binding repeats

Name: 4R tau
Description: Tau isoforms containing 4 tubulin binding repeats

Name: VQIINK motif
Description: A hexapeptide motif located in the R2, that promotes the formation of PHF

Name: VQIVYK motif
Description: A hexapeptide motif located in the R3, that promotes the formation of PHF

Name: ghost tangles
Description: Extracellular NFT remains after neuron death, considered to be the last stage of NFT-related pathological activity.

Name: pretangles
Description: Pretangles are cytoplasmic tau immunoreactivity in neurons without apparent formation of fibrillary structures. In Alzheimer disease, such tau deposition is considered to represent a premature state prior to fibril formation (AD-pretangles), later to form neurofibrillary tangles and finally ghost tangles.

Name: projection domain
Description: Corresponding roughly to the N-terminal part of the tau molecule, consisting mainly of acidic residues and containing two distinct alternatively spliced N-terminal inserts.

Name: RAC1b
Description: A constitutively active splicing isoform of RAC1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1), first identified in breast and colon cancer.

Name: AP-2 complex
Description: A heterotetrameric adapter protein complex involved in cargo-internalization during clathrin-mediated endocytosis. Composed of alpha and beta subunits (large adaptins), mu and sigma subunits (minor adaptins).

Name: Tau isoform F (441 aa)
Description: Longest tau isoform in human brain, most commonly used as the conventional tau.

Name: Tau isoform Fetal-tau (352 aa)
Description: Human fetal tau isoform.

Name: Tau isoform B (381 aa)
Description: Human brain tau isoform, derived from alternative splicing.

Name: Tau isoform D (383 aa)
Description: Human brain tau isoform, derived from alternative splicing.

Name: Tau isoform C (410 aa)
Description: Human brain tau isoform, derived from alternative splicing.

Name: Tau isoform E (412 aa)
Description: Human brain tau isoform, derived from alternative splicing.

Name: neuroinflammation
Description: inflammatory response in the brain and nervous tissue.

Name: neurotoxicity
Description: happens when a biological, physical or chemical agent cause any adverse effect on the structure and function of the nerves system.

Name: neurite retraction
Description: when the neurite is unable it outgrow and extend

Name: APP695
Description: the APP gene is located on chromosome 21 in humans with three major isoforms arising from alternative splicing [3]. These are APP695, APP751 and APP770 (containing 695, 751, and 770 amino acids, respectively)

Name: APP751
Description: the APP gene is located on chromosome 21 in humans with three major isoforms arising from alternative splicing [3]. These are APP695, APP751 and APP770 (containing 695, 751, and 770 amino acids, respectively)

Name: APP770
Description: the APP gene is located on chromosome 21 in humans with three major isoforms arising from alternative splicing [3]. These are APP695, APP751 and APP770 (containing 695, 751, and 770 amino acids, respectively)

Name: gamma-secretase
Description: gamma-secretase is a high molecular weight complex minimally composed of four components: presenilins (PS), nicastrin, anterior pharynx defective 1 (APH-1), and presenilin enhancer 2 (PEN-2)

Name: sAPP-alpha
Description: soluble amyloid precursor protein-alpha

Name: Excitotoxicity
Description: Excitotoxicity is defined as cell death resulting from the toxic actions of excitatory amino acids

Name: C31
Description: a fragment containing the last 31 amino acids of APP (called C31)

Name: Jcasp
Description: Additional gamma-cleavage further generates the fragment (called Jcasp) containing the region between gamma- and caspase-cleavage sites

Name: AICD
Description: APP intracellular domain

Name: p83
Description: APP alphaCTF and betaCTF are further cleaved by gamma-secretase to generate p83 and Abeta, respectively

Name: APP processing
Description: Any protein maturation process achieved by the cleavage of a peptide bond or bonds within a protein (see:GO:0016485)

Name: AβOs
Description: soluble Aβ oligomers

Name: LMW amyloid oligomers
Description: The formation of AβOs starts from alterations in the conformation of monomeric Aβ, resulting in low molecular weight (LMW) dimers and trimers, followed by aggregation to soluble spherical oligomers consisted of 12–24 monomers.

Name: amyloid-beta 40 oligomers
Description: Amyloid-beta oligomers composed specifically of amyloid-beta 40

Name: alternative splicing of APP gene
Description: The process of generating multiple mRNA molecules from a given set of exons by differential use of exons from the primary transcript(s) to form multiple mature mRNAs that vary in their exon composition (see:GO:0000380)

Name: E1 domain
Description: The ectodomains of APP and APLPs have two conserved regions called E1 and E2 (Fig. 1A), both of which have been proposed to contribute to dimerization

Name: E2 domain
Description: The ectodomains of APP and APLPs have two conserved regions called E1 and E2 (Fig. 1A), both of which have been proposed to contribute to dimerization

Name: P3 peptide
Description: Cleavage by α-secretase yields the nonamyloidogenic soluble 3-kDa peptide (p3) that does not form amyloid fibrils, whereas cleavage by β-secretase yields the amyloidogenic form Aβ1–40 or the longer, more fibrillogenic Aβ1–42

Name: C99
Description: a membrane associated C-terminal fragment consisting of 99 amino acids (C99)

Name: aMCI
Description: amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairement is a cognitive dysfunction that is associated with memory deficits

Name: mdMCI
Description: multi-domain Mild Cognitive Impairement is a cognitive dysfunction that is associated with more than one cognitive domain

Name: Tau isoform A (316 aa)
Description: Human brain tau isoform, derived from alternative splicing.

Name: Tau C3
Description: Tau epitope cleaved at aspartic acid(421).

Name: Tau MN423
Description: Tau epitope truncated at glutamic acid(391).

Name: granular tau oligomers
Description: When the oligomer lengthens, it adapts a beta-sheet structure and transforms into a detergent-insoluble aggregate with granular appearance under Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM)

Name: Tau fibrils
Description: As these granular tau oligomers fuse together, they form tau fibrils, which ultimately form NFTs

Name: dense core plaques
Description: Dense-core plaques are fibrillar deposits of Abeta, showing all the classical properties of amyloid including beta-sheet secondary structure, while diffuse plaques are amorphous deposits

Name: Tau annular protofibrils
Description: A handful of proteins implicated in neurodegenerative diseases have been found to produce pore-like amyloid structures known as annular protofibrils (APFs)

Name: TOC1
Description: monoclonal antibody, named TOC1 (tau oligomeric complex 1), which selectively labels tau dimers and oligomers, but does not label filaments

Name: alpha-synuclein fibrils
Description: fibrillar aggregates of alpha-synuclein, found in Lewy bodies

Name: alpha-synuclein oligomers
Description: oligomeric aggregates of alpha-synuclein

Name: CLR01
Description: the Lys-specific molecular tweezer CLR01 has been shown to inhibit aggregation and toxicity of multiple amyloidogenic protein

Name: prefibrillar α-synuclein oligomers
Description: prefibrillar oligomers formed at early stages of α-syn assembly

Name: GA-AGE
Description: Glyceraldehyde-derived (GA) advanced glycation end products

Name: TGM2 Isoform 3 (349 aa)
Description: Short isoform of tissue transglutaminase

Name: KXGS motif
Description: Conserved Tau phosphorylation motif. Part of the microtubule-binding region, phosphorylation of the serine in these motifs disrupts tau binding to the MT and serves to regulate tau-mediated MT assembly

Name: Corticobasal Degeneration
Description: CBD is a late-onset neurodegenerative disease involving the cerebral cortex and the basal ganglia, characterized by widespread deposition of hyperphosphorylated 4-repeat tau in neurons and glia, the latter as astrocytic plaques

Name: paired helical filaments
Description: Component of NFT, consisting in a helical arrangement of tau protomers

Name: straight filaments
Description: Component of NFT and ultrastructural polymorph of PHFs, with an assymetrical arrangement of the tau protomers

Name: Alz50
Description: Murine IgM-class monoclonal antibody recognizing a specific conformational epitope adopted by tau during PHF formation

Name: O-GlcNAcylation
Description: A non-canonical glycosylation involving the attachment of single O-linked N-acetylglucosamine (O-GlcNAc) moieties to serine and threonine residues of cytoplasmic, nuclear, and mitochondrial proteins

Name: glycation
Description: The non-enzymatic reaction between the electrophilic carbonyl groups of a reducing sugar and the free amino groups of tau amino acids (especially of basic lysine or arginine residues) leading to the formation of  a ketoamine (Amadori product), an intermediate of AGE synthesis.

Name: nitration
Description: Incorporation of a nitrogen dioxide (NO2) group in tyrosine residues (mostly) of proteins forming 3-nitrotyrosine (3-NT). A biomarker of cell, tissue and systemic nitrosative stress.

Name: polyamination
Description: The reaction of polyamination by transglutaminases (TGs) involves a glutamine (Q) as acyl donor and a lysine (K) as acyl acceptor. It generates a (gamma)-glutamyl-(epsilon)-lysine isopeptide bond that causes protein cross-linking

Name: formylation
Description: The addition of a formyl functional group usually at the epsilon amino group of Lys residues

Name: Syndecan Family
Description: IterPro:IPR001050

Name: Bacterial invasion
Description: The process of bacteria invading a cell

Name: dopamine homeostasis
Description: Dopmine secrete in a homeostatic way

Name: PINK1-Park pathway
Description: The PINK1-Parkin pathway promotes both mitophagy and selective respiratory chain turnover in vivo.pmid:23509287

Name: Glutamate excitotoxicity
Description: The excitotoxicity of Glutamate

Name: mitochondrial homeostasis
Description: The interplay between mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis.

Name: ER mitochondria interorganellar crosstalk
Description: reference:pmid: 22577383

Name: Mitochondrial pathway
Description: reference:pmid: 22399422

Name: oxidative protein folding
Description: Oxidative protein folding is a process that is responsible for the formation of disulfide bonds between cysteine residues in proteins. The driving force behind this process is a redox reaction, in which electrons pass between several proteins and finally to a terminal electron acceptor.

Name: mitochondrial motility
Description: The motility of mitochondria

Name: TIM/TOM complex
Description: The TIM/TOM complex is a protein complex in cellular biochemistry which translocates proteins produced from nuclear DNA through the mitochondrial membrane for use in oxidative phosphorylation. Only 13 proteins necessary for a mitochondrion are actually coded in mitochondrial DNA.

Name: mitochondrial aggregation
Description: The aggregation of mitochondria

Name: mevalonate pathway
Description: The mevalonate pathway, also known as the isoprenoid pathway or HMG-CoA reductase pathway is an essential metabolic pathway present in eukaryotes, archaea, and some bacteria

Name: Dopaminergic cell groups
Description: UBERON:dopaminergic cell groups

Name: mitochondrial precursor protein
Description: The precursor protein of mitochondria

Name: PDR-1
Description: the nematode homologs of Parkin

Name: PINK-1
Description: the nematode homologs of PINK1

Name: skn-1
Description: the nematode homologus of Skn1

Name: ced-9
Description: the nematode homologus of Bcl-2

Name: lgg-1
Description: the nematode homologus of Lgg1

Name: clec-65
Description: the nematode homologus of Clec65

Name: clec-4
Description: the nematode homologus of Clec4

Name: exotoxin A
Description: exotoxin A is an exotoxin produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.It inhibits elongation factor-2. It does so by ADP-ribosylation of EF2. This then causes the elongation of polypeptides to cease.

Name: mitochondrial DAMPs
Description: mitochondrial damage-associated molecular patterns

Name: IκB kinase
Description: The IκB kinase is an enzyme complex that is involved in propagating the cellular response to inflammation.

Name: non-shivering thermogenesis
Description: Nonshivering thermogenesis was originally defined as a cold-induced increase in heat production not associated with the muscle activity of shivering. Recent research shows it to be a metabolic process located primarily in brown adipose tissue and controlled by the activity of the sympathetic nervous supply of this tissue.PMID: 6722594

Name: hsp-16
Description: the nematode homologus of hsp16

Name: heat shock proteins
Description: Heat shock proteins (HSP) are a family of proteins that are produced by cells in response to exposure to stressful conditions. They were first described in relation to heat shock,

Name: high-calorie diets
Description: Diets with high calorie.

Name: proteotoxicity
Description: To function, proteins must undergo a folding process that gives them the proper three dimensional structure. Numerous genetic and biochemical observations suggest that proteins that fail to fold properly impair cell function. This process, also referred to as proteotoxicity, is particularly important to the fate of non-renewable cells of long-lived organisms in which malfolded proteins (proteotoxins) can exert their deleterious influence over extended periods of time.reference:Proteotoxicity and Aging

Name: ss20399075
Description: A SNP located within the 3' UTR of FGF20, is significantly associated with PD risk

Name: Alpha-synuclein Oligomerization
Description: The formation of alpha-synuclein oligmer

Name: D6S253
Description: A microsatellite markers for Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s Diseases

Name: D6S305
Description: A microsatellite markers for Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s Diseases

Name: MTHFR,TT+AA
Description: In Parkinson's Disease, TT+AA is more frequent in MTHFR gene.

Name: CAG repeats
Description: CAG repeats in genes.

Name: Gastrointestinal dysfunctions
Description: The function of gastrotestine disorder.

Name: olfactory epithelium
Description: UBERON:olfactory epithelium

Name: nasal cycle
Description: The nasal cycle is the often unnoticed alternating partial congestion and decongestion of the nasal cavities in humans and other animals. It is a physiological congestion of the nasal concha, also called the nasal turbinate, due to selective activation of one half of the autonomic nervous system by the hypothalamus.

Name: hyposmia
Description: Hyposmia is a reduced ability to smell and to detect odors.Hyposmia might be a very early sign of Parkinson's disease. Hyposmia is also an early and almost universal finding in Alzheimer's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies. Lifelong hyposmia could be caused by Kallmann syndrome.

Name: FMR1,(55-200 CGG)
Description: A premutation (PM) expansion (55-200 CGG) in the fragile X mental retardation gene 1 causes elevated messenger RNA and reduced fragile X mental retardation gene 1 protein.

Name: pof14
Description: a new member of the F-box family, Pof14, which forms a canonical

Name: Neuroglia
Description: MeSH Unique ID: D009457

Name: GDNF Family
Description: The GDNF family of ligands (GFL) consists of four neurotrophic factors: glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF), neurturin (NRTN), artemin (ARTN), and persephin (PSPN). GFLs have been shown to play a role in a number of biological processes including cell survival, neurite outgrowth, cell differentiation and cell migration. In particular signalling by GDNF promotes the survival of dopaminergic neurons.

Name: Motor Neurons
Description: MeSH Unique ID: D009046

Name: noradrenergic neuron
Description: Cell:noradrenergic neuron

Name: midbrain dopaminergic neuron
Description: Cell:midbrain dopaminergic neuron

Name: Neurites
Description: A neurite or neuronal process refers to any projection from the cell body of a neuron.

Name: GRB10,BPS domain
Description: BPS domain of protein GRB10

Name: common fragile site
Description: A chromosomal fragile site is a specific heritable point on a chromosome that tends to form a gap or constriction and may tend to break when the cell is exposed to partial replication stress.Based on their frequency, fragile sites are classified as common or rare.To date, more than 120 fragile sites have been identified in the human genome.

Name: PARK7-alpha helices
Description: The alpja helices of PARK7 protein

Name: cleaved PINK1
Description: The cleaved part of Protein PINK1

Name: neurovascular unit
Description: The brain hyperaemia, or coupling, is accomplished by a group of cells, closely related to each other; called neurovascular unit (NVU). The neurovascular unit is composed by neurones, astrocytes, endothelial cells of blood-brain barrier (BBB), myocytes, pericytes and extracellular matrix components. reference:PMID: 24629161

Name: Muscles
Description: MeSH Unique ID: D009132

Name: Neural Stem Cell
Description: MeSH Unique ID: D058953

Name: Ventral Tegmental Area
Description: MeSH Unique ID: D017557

Name: Pars Compacta
Description: MeSH Unique ID: D065842

Name: proline-rich domain
Description: Correspounding to residues I151 to Q244 of the 441 aa tau isoform, separated into P1 and P2. Possible role in tau's functional stabilization through the reported intramolecular interaction of P2 with R1, R2 and R4 from the microtubule-binding region

Name: lys-2
Description: the nematode homologus of Lys2

Name: abf-2
Description: the nematode homologus of Abf2

Name: hydrophobic pocket of actin
Description: The lower cleft between domains 1 and 3 is lined by residues Tyr143, Ala144, Gly146, Thr148, Gly168, Ile341, Ile345, Leu346, Leu349, Thr351, and Met355, which are predominantly hydrophobic. This cleft constitutes the major binding site for most ABPs and also mediates important longitudinal contacts between actin subunits in the filament

Name: 310-helix
Description: The 310-helix is the fourth most common type of secondary structure in proteins after α-helices, β-sheets, and reverse turns (Barlow and Thornton 1988). Approximately 15%–20% of all helices in protein structures are 310-helices, which are commonly found as N- or C-terminal extensions to an α-helix (Barlow and Thornton 1988). 310-Helices in proteins are typically only three to five residues long compared with a mean of 10–12 residues for α-helices (Richardson and Richardson 1988)

Name: Amylin Antagonist AC253
Description: Amino Acid Sequence: Ac-Leu-Gly-Arg-Leu-Ser-Gln-Glu-Leu-His-Arg-Leu-Gln-Thr-Tyr-Pro-Arg-Thr-Asn-Thr-Gly-Ser-Asn-Thr-Tyr-NH2

Name: CDK5R1 p25
Description: The cyclin dependent kinase 5 regulatory subunit 1 (CDK5R1), also known as p35, is cleaved by Calpain to produce the p25 fragment

Name: PTI-125
Description: PTI-125 is a small molecule that preferentially binds altered FLNA and restores its native conformation, restoring receptor and synaptic activities and reducing its alpha7nAChR/TLR4 associations and downstream pathologies

Name: alpha-4 beta-2 nAChR
Description: In addition to nAChRs forming from different subunit assemblages, stoichiometric study has shown that α4β2 nAChRs can form as either (α4)3(β2)2 or (α4)2(β2)3, the latter having a greater affinity for both nicotine and Ach

Name: alpha-7 beta-2 nAChR
Description: Accumulating evidence demonstrates that these α7 and β2 nAChR subunits can co-assemble to form functional α7β2 nAChRs in heterologous expression systems, and also under natural conditions in the brain (Figure 1)

Name: beta-2-containing nAChR
Description: The β2 subunit can couple with non-α4 subunits, including α2, α3 and α6 subunits to form functionally distinct nAChRs, but these receptors are much less densely expressed in the central nervous system relative to α4β2* nAChRs (*indicating potential assemblage of β2 subunits with non-α4 subunits)

Name: Abeta*56
Description: 56 kDa soluble amyloid-β (Aβ) assembly

Name: protein aggregates
Description: Aggregates of proteins or fragments of proteins

Name: sAPP-gamma
Description: results from the cleavage of beta APP by gamma-secretase

Name: alpha-6-containing nAChR
Description: alpha6-containing receptors, which in brain occur as heteropentamers with beta2 and beta3 and are especially enriched in presynaptic nerve terminals in striatum (Champtiaux et al.,2002)

Name: phosphatase-activating domain
Description: Tau domain located in the N-terminal region encompassing residues 2-18. It activates phosphatase PP1 which dephosphorylates Ser9 in GSK3Beta and leads to its activation. In normal tau, both NTD and CTD are folded back in proximity to each other forming a 'paper-clip' conformation, which masks the PAD. Phosphorylation in the AT8 epitope, disrupts this normal conformational state, exposing the PAD by moving away the terminal domains.

Name: cystein-dependent auto-acetylation
Description: Autocatalytic cysteine-mediated acetylation of Lys residues in the MTBR upon incubation of tau proteins with acetyl-CoA, possible even in absence of enzymatic activity.This activity may be suppressed when tau is bound to tubulin or MTs, but activated upon tau dissociation during pathological conditions that abrogate tau-MT interactions, thus allowing acetyl-CoA accessibility to free tau cysteines.

Name: GVD bodies
Description: Pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer Disease, consisting in intraneuronal accumulations of large membrane-bound vacuoles. Associated with the late stages of disease progression, they were also shown to be immunopositive or GSK3Beta and SYK (Spleen Tyrosine Kinase).

Name: advanced glycation end product
Description: Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) are the production of Maillard reaction between carbohydrates and proteins. They cause neurotoxicity via production of ROS followed by an increase in expression of APP and amyloid beta. Recent analysis implicates them in tau phosphorylation.

Name: long-term potentiation
Description: A long lasting enhancement in synaptic transmission between two neurons, most commonly studied in the synapse between the Schaffer collateral axons of the CA3 neurons and the CA1 pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Alongside the LTD (long-term depression) represent the two mechanisms of memory formation and storage. Impairment of this process in AD is caused by soluble oligmoeric amyloid beta.

Name: proline-rich region 1
Description: Part of the wider proline-rich domain, divided between the projection and assembly domains, this region together with the MTBR mediate tau interaction and binding to F actin.

Name: proline-rich region 2
Description: Part of the wider proline-rich domain, divided between the projection and assembly domains, this region together with the MTBR mediate tau interaction and binding to F actin.

Name: assembly domain
Description: Tau assembly domain consists of the second part of the proline-rich region (PR2), MTBR and CTD, corresponding to residues 199-441 of the canonical tau isoform.

Name: CRL4 complex
Description: Cullin-RING E3 ubiquitin ligase complex 4, consisting of CUL4(A,B), DDB1 and CRBN.

Name: APP, ACR
Description: Cytosolic region of APP, responsible for interacting with E3 ubiquitin ligases among other proteins.

Name: tubulin detyrosination
Description: Detyrosination is a form of posttranslational modification that occurs on alpha-tubulin. It consists of the removal of the C-terminal tyrosine to expose a glutamate at the newly formed C-terminus. Promoted by Tau truncation in the Gln124 residue.

Name: Microgliosis
Description: An intense reaction of microglia following CNS insult, characterized by active proliferation and retracted cellular processes. In AD, accumulation of Abeta can be a possible cause of such physiological phenomenon, as microglia is seen surrounding senile plaques. Abeta interaction with microglial pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) leads to NLRP3 inflammasome activation, production of toxic NOS and ROS and release of proinflammatory cytokines.

Name: Astrogliosis
Description: Morphological and functional changes observed in astrocytes in the context of their physiological response to CNS trauma or injury caused by ischemia, stroke, autoimmune disorders and neurodegeneration.

Name: CK1 superfamily
Description: The CK1 group of eukaryotic protein kinases are composed of seven CK1 isoforms (CK1α, CK1α2, CK1δ, CK1ε, CK1γ1, CK1γ2, and CK1γ3), two Tau–tubulin kinase isoforms (TTBK1 and TTBK2), and three VRK isoforms (VRK1, VRK2, and VRK3)

Name: alpha-4-containing nAChR
Description: nAChRs that bind radiolabeled nicotine with the highest afﬁnity contain a4 subunits (a4*-nAChR)

Name: alpha-4 beta-4 nAChR
Description: a4 subunits can also assemble with b4 subunits to form a4b4-nAChRs that have comparably high nicotine afﬁnity

Name: alpha-7-containing nAChR
Description: Another prominent nAChR subtype found in vertebrate central and autonomic nervous systems contains a7 subunits.

Name: alpha-Bungarotoxin
Description: Neurotoxic proteins from the venom of the banded or Formosan krait (Bungarus multicinctus, an elapid snake).

Name: alpha-3 beta-2 nAChR
Description: nAChRs containing the a3b2 subunit interface

Name: kappa-Bungarotoxin
Description: kappa-Bungarotoxin, a snake venom kappa-neurotoxin, is a potent neuronal nicotinic receptor antagonist (pmid:3359187)

Name: VU10010
Description: highly selective M4 (mAChR) allosteric potentiator. Chemical name: 3-Amino-N-[(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]-4,6-dimethylthieno[2,3-b]pyridine-2-carboxamide

Name: VU0456940
Description: M1-selective PAM that potentiates M1 (mAChR). Chemical name:1-[4,6-difluoro-1-[6-(1-methylpyrazol-4-yl)pyridin-3-yl]indol-3-yl]sulfonyl-3-(5-methyl-1,2-oxazol-3-yl)propan-2-one

Name: VU0152099
Description: selective M4 (mAChR) allosteric potentiator. Chemical name: 3-Amino-N-(1,3-benzodioxol-5-ylmethyl)-4,6-dimethylthieno[2,3-b]pyridine-2-carboxamide

Name: VU0029767
Description: selective M1(mAChR)-PAM. Chemical name: 2-(4-Ethoxyanilino)-N'-[(Z)-(2-oxonaphthalen-1-ylidene)methyl]acetohydrazide

Name: VU0090157
Description: selective M1(mAChR)-PAM. Chemical name: Cyclopentyl 3,4-dimethyl-6-(6-nitro-1,3-benzodioxol-5-yl)-2-oxo-1,6-dihydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate

Name: VU0184670
Description: M1(mAChR) allosteric agonists. Chemical name: Ethyl 4-(2-benzamidoethylamino)piperidine-1-carboxylate hydrochloride

Name: 2-Bromohexadecanoic acid
Description: Inhibits Fyn localization in lipid rafts and subsequently inhibits the fyn-dependent Abeta redistribution and accumulation in lipid rafts, process linked with ADDL-induced cell death.

Name: 20 S Proteasome
Description: The catalytic core of the 26 S proteasome system, responsible for tau degradation

Name: 3-3 dityrosine cross-linking
Description: An oxidation product consisting of covalent ortho-ortho coupling between two tyrosine residues formed as a conseguence to UV irradiation, gamma-irradiation, aging, exposure to oxygen free radicals, nitrogen dioxide, peroxynitrite, and lipid hydroperoxides.  ROS catalyzed by Cu ions are involved in the generation of these cross-links in amyloid beta oligomers to which they provide stability. Also involved in the stabilization of tau PHF. A potential biomarker of oxidative stress in AD.

Name: Braak_Stage I
Description: A disease propagation and progression model, composed of six stages of increasing pathological severity determined by the location of the tangle-bearing neurons and the amplitude of the pathophysiological changes. Transentorhinal stages I-II: correspond to clinically silent cases of very mildly affected subjects, showing no cognitive impairment. NFT are slowly and gradually developping.

Name: Braak_Stage II
Description: A disease propagation and progression model, composed of six stages of increasing pathological severity determined by the location of the tangle-bearing neurons and the amplitude of the pathophysiological changes. Transentorhinal stages I-II: correspond to clinically silent cases of very mildly affected subjects, showing no cognitive impairment. NFT are slowly and gradually developping.

Name: Braak_Stage III
Description: A disease propagation and progression model, composed of six stages of increasing pathological severity determined by the location of the tangle-bearing neurons and the amplitude of the pathophysiological changes.Limbic stages III-IV designate an incipient Alzheimer's disease, since due to the lack of neocortical destruction, stages III and IV do not meet the currently used criteria for neuropathologic diagnosis of AD.  Stage III is characterised by the destruction of the external principal stratum of the entorhinal laminae presenting considerable amounts of NFT and neuropil threads.

Name: Braak_Stage IV
Description: A disease propagation and progression model, composed of six stages of increasing pathological severity determined by the location of the tangle-bearing neurons and the amplitude of the pathophysiological changes.Limbic stages III-IV designate an incipient Alzheimer's disease, since due to the lack of neocortical destruction, stages III and IV do not meet the currently used criteria for neuropathologic diagnosis of AD.  Stage IV is characterised by the destruction of the internal principal stratum of the entorhinal laminae presenting considerable amounts of NFT and neuropil threads. The destruction of entorhinal cellular layers interferes with the normal transfer of information between neocortex and hippocampus, manifesting as cognitive impairment and subtle personality changes.

Name: Braak_Stage V
Description: A disease propagation and progression model, composed of six stages of increasing pathological severity determined by the location of the tangle-bearing neurons and the amplitude of the pathophysiological changes.neocortical stages V-VI correspond to fully developed Alzheimer's disease. These stages are characterized by large numbers of NFTs in all sections of cerebral cortex and present neocortical damage thus contributing to the development of the conventional neuropathological criteria for the clinical diagnosis of AD.

Name: Braak_Stage VI
Description: A disease propagation and progression model, composed of six stages of increasing pathological severity determined by the location of the tangle-bearing neurons and the amplitude of the pathophysiological changes.neocortical stages V-VI correspond to fully developed Alzheimer's disease. These stages are characterized by large numbers of NFTs in all sections of cerebral cortex and present neocortical damage thus contributing to the development of the conventional neuropathological criteria for the clinical diagnosis of AD.

Name: CagA peptide
Description: A peptide with sequence:GFPLKRHDGVDDLSKVG, originally synthesized by Helicobacter Pylori acting as a specific MARK kinase inhibitor, decreasing tau phosphorylation

Name: MARK4 isoform 2 (688 aa)
Description: Shortest isoform of Microtubule affinity regulating kinase 4 (MARK4) derived from alternatvie splicing. It is upregulated during the early stages of neuron differentiation.

Name: NP_001387.2:p.Arg205del
Description: Loss of function mutant of DYRK1A isoform 1

Name: NP_001387.2:p.Glu239del
Description: Loss of function mutant of DYRK1A isoform 1

Name: PrP106-126
Description: Prion protein fragment 106-126. This peptide increases membrane microviscosity, intracellular Ca2+ concentration and cell migration in circulating leucocytes, and oxygen production in monocytes and neutrophils. It also induces apoptotic cell death and impairment of L-type voltage-sensitive calcium channel activity in the GH3 cell lines. PrP (106–126) stimulates leucocyte migration in a dose-dependent manner. Inhibits tau phosphorylaton at Ser262. Seq = KTNMKHMAGAAAAGAVVGGLG

Name: Purkinje cell layer of cerebellar cortex
Description: The Purkinje cell layer lies just underneath the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex. It contains the neuronal cell bodies of the Purkinje cells that are arranged side by side in a single layer. Candelabrum interneurons are vertically oriented between the Purkinje cells. Purkinje neurons are inhibitory and provide the output of the cerebellar cortex through axons that project into the white matter. Extensive dendritic trees from the Purkinje cells extend upward in a single plane into the molecular layer where they synapse with parallel fibers of granule cells.

Name: Tau antibody, AGG5759
Description: Tau antibody with specificity for pSer262

Name: Tau antibody, Tau-13
Description: Tau murine monoclonal antibody with specificity for pSer262

Name: Tau epitope, 12E8
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pSer262 and pSer356

Name: Tau epitope, AT180
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pThr231

Name: Tau epitope, AT8
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pSer202, pThr205, pSer208, pSer199

Name: Tau epitope, CP13
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pSer202

Name: Tau epitope, PHF1
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pSer396, pSer404

Name: dystrophic neurite
Description: Dysfunctional axons and terminals that accumulate the β-site amyloid precursor protein (APP) cleaving enzyme (BACE1) required for Aβ generation.

Name: granular layer of cerebellar cortex
Description: The granular layer is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex. This layer contains densely packed small neurons, mostly granule cells. Some Golgi cells are found at the outer border. Granule neurons send parallel fibers to the upper molecular layer, where they synapse with Purkinje cell dendrites. Mossy fibers from the pontine nuclei in the white matter synapse with granule cell axons, Golgi cell axons and unipolar brush interneuron axons at cerebellar glomeruli in the granule cell layer

Name: molecular layer of cerebellar cortex
Description: The molecular layer is the outermost layer of the cerebellar cortex. It contains the parallel fibers of the granule cells, interneurons such as stellate and basket cells, and the dendrites of the underlying Purkinje cells

Name: Kalirin 7
Description: Isoform of KALRN protein

Name: 4R tauopathy
Description: Tauopathies characterized by a relatively higher presence of the 4R tau isoforms, such as Alzheimers Disease and Corticobasal Degeneration

Name: ACY-1215
Description: Ricolinostat is an orally bioavailable, specific inhibitor of histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6) with potential antineoplastic activity. Ricolinostat selectively targets and binds to HDAC6, thereby disrupting the Hsp90 protein chaperone system through hyperacetylation of Hsp90 and preventing the subsequent aggresomal protein degradation. This leads to an accumulation of unfolded and misfolded ubiquitinated proteins and may eventually induce cancer cell apoptosis, and inhibition of cancer cell growth. HDAC6, a class II HDAC deacetylase located in the cytoplasm, appears to play a key role in the formation and activation of the aggresomes needed for degradation of misfolded proteins. Compared to non-selective HDAC inhibitor, ACY-1215 is able to reduce the toxic effects on normal, healthy cells.

Name: APOE e3
Description: Interacts with tubulin binding repeat 1

Name: BAY61-3606
Description: A cell-permeable imidazopyrimidine compound that acts a potent, ATP-competitive, reversible, and highly selective inhibitor of Syk tyrosine kinase activity (IC50 = 10 nM) with no inhibitory effect against Btk, Fyn, Itk, Lyn, and Src even at concentrations as high as 4.7 µM. Shown to inhibit Syk-mediated cellular functions in vitro and exhibit good oral bioavailability and in vivo effacacy in the treatment of various allgery and asthma conditions in rat models. Indirect inhibitory effect on GSK3B activity

Name: Biphenyl-4-yl-acrylohydroxamoc acids
Description: Chemical compund group acting as inhibitors of HDAC family proteins.

Name: Brodmann (1909) area 36
Description: Ectorhinal area 36 is a subdivision of the cytoarchitecturally defined temporal region of cerebral cortex. With its medial boundary corresponding approximately to the rhinal sulcus it is located primarily in the fusiform gyrus. Cytoarchitecturally it is bounded laterally and caudally by the inferior temporal area 20, medially by the perirhinal area 35 and rostrally by the temporopolar area 38 (H) (Brodmann-1909). Together with Brodmann area 35, it comprises the perirhinal cortex.

Name: C-30-27
Description: PCAF and NFkappaB inhibitor, showed anti-inflammatory properties and improved cognition

Name: C646
Description: Inhibitor of EP300 acetylase

Name: CA1 field of hippocampus
Description: Part of hippocampus proper bounded by CA2 and the subiculum, characterized by pyramidal neurons that receive projections from pyramidal neurons of CA3 via the Schaffer collaterals.

Name: CA2 field of hippocampus
Description: Part of hippocampus proper bounded by areas CA3 and CA1, characterized by a narrow layer of large pyramidal cells, similar in size to CA3 pyramidal cells, but which lack the mossy fiber input from the dentate gyrus

Name: CA3 field of hippocampus
Description: Part of hippocampus proper bounded by the hilus of the dentate gyrus and area CA2, characterized by large pyramidal cells and a dense projection from dentate gyrus granule cell mossy fibers.

Name: CA4 field of hippocampus
Description: The last of four regions in the cornu ammonis of the hippocampus and is also part of the hilus of the dentate gyrus. This area contains mostly mossy cells that receive inputs from the dentate gyrus and pyramidal cells in the CA3 region and also projects back to the dentate gyrus.

Name: CGP3466B
Description: Inhibitor of GAPDH nitrosylation, abrogated Abeta induced tau acetylation and subsequent pathological impairments related to AD

Name: CM-414
Description: A dual inhibitor of PDE5 and HDACs, chronic treatment of Tg2576 mice, a well characterized AD mouse model, showed decreased Ab and Tau phsophorylation and inhibition of GSK3B activity.

Name: DAPK, basic loop (BL) motif
Description: A structural motif of DAPK (Death-Associated Protein Kinase) positively regulating the kinase activity.

Name: Histone H3
Description: One of the five main histone proteins of chromatin structure, acetylation at Lys 9 was positively linked with the transcriptional activation of various genes involved in neuro-regeneration following peripheral axonal injury, among which BDNF.

Name: ID-8
Description: Inhibitor of GSK3Beta and DYRK1 kinases

Name: LDN-193594
Description: A synthetic derviative of 2,4-diaminothiazole serving as an inhibitor of CDK5 kinase acitivty and of tau PHF1 epitope phosphorylation

Name: LDN-193665
Description: A synthetic derviative of 2,4-diaminothiazole with a lesser powerful inhibitory effect on CDK5, but a potent inhibitor of Gsk3b

Name: LDN-213843
Description: Small molecule of the diaminothiazole class, acting as inhibitor of CDK5 and GSK3Beta kinases

Name: Long-Term Depression
Description: A gradual weakening of neuronal synaptic connections lasting hours or longer following a long patterned stimulus. Along with LTP (long term potentiation) is one of the main mechanisms of memory formation, more specifically of spatial memory. The mechanism involves an interplay of NMDA and AMPA glutamate receptors, with minimal intracellular calcium levels triggering a cellular cascade leading to the removal of the latter and an overall decrease of the glutammate receptors in the postsynaptic neurons, thus weakening the synapse.

Name: Pathological Tau Spreading
Description: Pathological spreading pattern of tau into defined anatomycally interconnected brain regions during the progression of tauopathy.

Name: PrPSc
Description: PrPSc (scrapie isoform of the prion protein) prions are the infectious agent behind diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans, bovine spongiform encephalopathy in cattle, chronic wasting disease in cervids (deer, elk, moose, and reindeer), as well as goat and sheep scrapie. PrPSc is an alternatively folded variant of the cellular prion protein, PrPC, which is a regular, GPI-anchored protein that is present on the cell surface of neurons and other cell types.

Name: Tau Protein Secondary Structure, Turn
Description: A turn-like structure formed in tau as a conseguence of the phosphorylation of only Ser202 and Thr205 residues, protects against aggregation.

Name: Tau antibody, RG7345
Description: RG7345 is a humanized monoclonal antibody targeting the tau phosphoepitope pS422. Tau phosphorylated at this site is considered a pathological form that has been linked to the relocalization of tau away from microtubules and toward the somato-dendritic compartment of the neuron.

Name: RGFP966
Description: Selective inhibitor of HDAC3

Name: SL-327
Description: Inhibitor of MAP2K1/2 kinases activity in murine neuroblastoma cell line N2A

Name: Spinocerebellar Ataxia 11
Description: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 11 (SCA11) is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia and abnormal eye signs (jerky pursuit, horizontal and vertical nystagmus). Caused by mutations in the TTBK2 (Tau Tubulin Kinase 2) gene, is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

Name: ST7612AA1
Description: A thiol derivative, pan-HDAC inhibitor

Name: Tau antibody, AGG5759
Description: Rabbit polyclonal antibody against tau pSer262, AstraZeneca

Name: Tau epitope, AD2
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pThr396 and pSer404

Name: Tau epitope, AP422
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pSer422

Name: Tau epitope, AT100
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pSer212 and pThr214

Name: Tau epitope, AT270
Description: Tau epitope consisting of pThr181

Name: Thiamet G
Description: Inhibitor of O-GlcNAcase (OGA)

Name: Thioflavin S
Description: Dye binding to PHF used in AD diagnostics

Name: Trithiocarbonates
Description: Chemical compound group of susbtrate competitive selective HDAC6 inhibitors

Name: Tubacin
Description: Inhibitor of HDAC6

Name: Tubastatin A
Description: Inhibitor of HDAC6 shown to also decrease tau hyperphosphorylation and Ab load

Name: USP14 Aptamer
Description: Inhibitory oligopeptide of the USP14, a deubiquitinating enzyme.

Name: cholinergic neuron
Description: A neuron that uses acetylcholine as a vesicular neurotransmitter.

Name: cerebral cortex
Description: The thin layer of gray matter on the surface of the cerebral hemisphere that develops from the telencephalon. It consists of the neocortex (6 layered cortex or isocortex), the hippocampal formation and the olfactory cortex.

Name: crebinostat
Description: Inhibitor of HDAC6

Name: diaminothiazole
Description: Compound class with kinase inhibition properties, specifically for CDK5 and GSK3Beta

Name: entorhinal cortex layer 2
Description: Layer of the entorhinal cortex lying superficial to layer 3 and deep to layer 1. It is characterized by medium-to large sized stellate cells that are grouped into prominent clusters, particularly in the rostral entorhinal cortex.

Name: granular layer of cerebellar cortex
Description: The granular layer is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex. This layer contains densely packed small neurons, mostly granule cells. Some Golgi cells are found at the outer border. Granule neurons send parallel fibers to the upper molecular layer, where they synapse with Purkinje cell dendrites. Mossy fibers from the pontine nuclei in the white matter synapse with granule cell axons, Golgi cell axons and unipolar brush interneuron axons at cerebellar glomeruli in the granule cell layer.

Name: indirubin
Description: A powerful inhibitor of GSK3B

Name: isocarboxazide
Description: Inhibitor of tau aggregation

Name: isopentanyladenine
Description: Inhibitor of CKD5 activity

Name: maitotoxin
Description: Increases intracellular calcium levels, and induces the association of TGM2 with tau, positively affecting the activity of the former

Name: olomoucine
Description: Inhibitor of CKD5 activity

Name: oxazolidinedione
Description: Inhibitor of tau aggregation

Name: sudoxicam
Description: Inhibitor of tau aggregation

Name: thiohydantoin
Description: Inhibitor of tau aggregation

Name: thioxooxazolidine
Description: Inhibitor of tau aggregation

Name: tideglusib
Description: Irreversibly inhibits GSK3B activity

Name: Tau antibody, 6C5
Description: human monoclonal antibody that targets tau epitope 125-131

Name: Tau antibody, HT7
Description: mouse monoclonal antibody that targets tau epitope 159-163

Name: 6-O-sulfated heparin
Description: During synthesis the HS chains are selectively sulfated at the N, 6-O, and 3-O positions of the glucosamine (GlcNS) and at the 2-O position of the uronic acid residue by HS sulfotransferases and modified by C5-epimerization of glucuronic acid (GlcA) to iduronic acid (IdoA)

Name: 2-O-sulfated heparin
Description: During synthesis the HS chains are selectively sulfated at the N, 6-O, and 3-O positions of the glucosamine (GlcNS) and at the 2-O position of the uronic acid residue by HS sulfotransferases and modified by C5-epimerization of glucuronic acid (GlcA) to iduronic acid (IdoA)

Name: sonicated tau fibrils
Description: To make sonicated fibril samples, fibrillized protein was sonicated using a MiSonix Sonicator 4000 (QSonica, LLC) at 50% amplitude for 60 1 s pulses

Name: Tau antibody, 40E8
Description: human monoclonal antibody that targets tau epitope 195-212 (pS202 and pT205)

Name: Tau antibody, pS396
Description: rabbit polyclonal antibody that targets tau pS396

Name: Tau antibody, 4E4
Description: human monoclonal antibody that targets tau epitope 385-395

Name: Tau antibody, Tau46
Description: mouse monoclonal antibody that targets tau epitope 404-441

Name: cis p-tau
Description: The cis conformation of phosphorylated tau is considered to be the main pathogenic tau agent associated with AD neurological impairments. PIN1, a peptidyl-prolyl-cis-transe isomerase, catalizes the rotation of the peptidic bond directly before proline residues inducing a conversion toward the trans conformation, therefore reducing the presence of the pathogenic cis tau isomers.

Name: MPT0G211
Description: MPT0G211 is a novel potent, selective HDAC6 inhibitor with IC50 of 0.291 nM, displays >1,000-fold selectivity over other HDAC isoforms; significantly inhibits tau phosphorylation on Ser396, Ser404, and phosphorylated tau (p-tau) aggregation, significantly attenuates apoptosis induced by p-tau, inhibits HDAC6/Hsp90 binding and causes subsequent proteasomal degradation of polyubiquitinated proteins; ameliorates learning and memory impairment in animal models of Alzheimer's disease, reduces the amount of phosphorylated tau in the hippocampal CA1 region; also demonstrates antiproliferative activity against human multiple myeloma RPMI 8226, U266, and NCI-H929 cells with no effect on normal bone marrow cells.

Name: peripheral nervous system injury
Description: PNS injuries initiate a signaling cascade that induces neuroregeneration. This cascade involves activation of ERK, subsequently leading to the activation of PCAF (KAT2B), which in turn mediates histone 3 acetylation, paving the way for transcriptional activation of the key genes in the regeneration program.

Name: Tau antibody, TNT1
Description: Murine monoclonal IgG recognizing the phosphatase-activating domain (PAD) of tau

Name: Tau antibody, TNT2
Description: Murine monoclonal IgG recognizing the phosphatase-activating domain (PAD) of tau

Name: 8-nitro-cGMP
Description: One of the major endogenus cGMP derivatives, a class of second messengers in the nitric oxide signalling pathway. It modifies the target protein's cysteine residues via a stable sulfide bond through the NO group of the guanine base, in a post translational modification also known as S-guanylation, a process involved in the regulation of the physiological roles of several important proteins. The S-guanylation of tau was shown to block the aggregation process and the subsequent formation of tau oligomers.

Name: Tau dimers
Description: A key intermediate product of tau oligomerization to PHF and NFT formation, they consist of covalently linked antiparallel tau monomers presenting disulfide cross links between cystein residues.

Name: polysumoylation
Description: A post-translational modification consisting on the addition and covalent bonding of multiple SUMO (small ubiquitin-like modifiers) proteins to lysine residues of target proteins, mediating a wide range of physiological functions. Polysumoylation of APP was found to reduce the generation of amyloid beta peptides, while mono or under-sumoylation enhance Ab generation.

Name: detyrosination
Description: Detyrosination is a form of posttranslational modification that occurs on alpha-tubulin. It consists of the removal of the C-terminal tyrosine to expose a glutamate at the newly formed C-terminus.

Name: Tau antibody
Description: Antibodies for the Tau protein (HGNC:MAPT)

Name: Tau epitope
Description: Epitopes targed by antibodies for the Tau protein (HGNC:MAPT)

Name: S 24795
Description: A partial agonist at α7 nAChR

Name: GTS-21
Description: GTS-21 is a derivative of the natural product anabaseine that acts as a partial agonist at neural nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It binds to both the α4β2 and α7 subtypes, but activates only the α7 to any significant extent.

Name: alpha-4 alpha-5 beta-2 nAChR
Description: nAChR subtype found in cortex, hippocampus and neostriatum

Name: alpha-3 beta-4 nAChR
Description: nAChR subtype found in hippocampus, pineal gland and cerebellum

Name: alpha-3 beta-3 beta-4 nAChR
Description: nAChR subtype found in habenula and interpeduncular nucleus

Name: alpha-6 beta-2 beta-3 nAChR
Description: nAChR subtype found in locus coeruleus, substantia nigra and neostriatum

Name: alpha-2 beta-2 nAChR
Description: nAChR subtype found in interpeduncular nucleus

Name: alpha-6 alpha-4 beta-2 beta-3 nAChR
Description: nAChR subtype found in neostriatum

Name: protein aggregation
Description: Protein aggregation occurs in vivo as a result of improper folding or misfolding

Name: Isolation rearing
Description: An animal model in which rats, immediately after weaning (usually postnatal day 21), are housed in isolation from siblings for an extended period (usually several weeks). In adulthood, these animals show many characteristics also seen in patients with schizophrenia
